awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Towards Securing Social Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
Robotics has traditionally focused on industrial and medical applications until recently with the development of robots, known as social robots, that are designed to intelligently and socially interact with humans. There has been little research on the privacy and security implications of these social robots. Moreover, with the potential wide-spread use of social robots in the next decade for the home, office, and daily living activities, high among the societal challenges will be protecting our privacy and ensuring security of social robots in wide-use.  

This research project addresses the cyber security of social robots, their vulnerabilities and risks. There are four primary objectives of this project: (1) seek to uncover security vulnerabilities of a social robot by focusing on the tools used to program these robots, its sensors and actuators; (2) develop algorithms capable of detecting whether a social robot has been compromised and violated privacy and security directives; (3) analyze relevant capabilities of current social robot prototypes; and, (4) investigate privacy and usability issues of a social robot. In addition, a summer camp at Marquette University on cyber security with special sessions on privacy and security in robotics, and especially social robots, is planned for students and teachers in southeastern Wisconsin.

por.por_cntn:
Social robots are artificially intelligent (AI) devices that aim to provide a more human-like interaction. Apart from the purely scientific interest, the number of companies that are bringing to the market robots meant to live and socially interact with people has steadily been increasing over the last decade. These AI devices are designed to reside in personal spaces, such as homes or senior living facilities, carry many sensors and may be mobile.

This project is the first to inquire into potential cybersecurity and privacy vulnerabilities of social robots and offer prototype solutions to some of the emerging issues. The project uncovered security vulnerabilities of two social robots and designed techniques to detect whether such a robot has been compromised. It also looked at perceptions a diverse group of people had towards social robots regarding their usability and privacy. To address privacy concerns, the project designed and implemented an auditability mechanism based on public blockchain through which consumers could track the use of their data by service providers.

Activities included a week long summer cybersecurity workshop for high school students and teachers as well as four sessions during which more than 100 participants interacted with social robots. Participants ranged from high school students to adults and older adults in a senior living facility in a metropolitan US area. Results of the project were communicated to robot manufacturers and published to the research community. Two graduate and three undergraduate students were trained and actively engaged in the project's research.
